Complex orientations of Thom spectra

Mar 25, 2019

Sorry for the long silence; I’ve been busy with midterms and studying for the GRE. I want to talk about a question that’s been on the back burner for quite a while. There’s a miraculous theorem of Hopkins and Mahowald, which states that the free -ring with a nullhomotopy of is equivalent as an -ring to . More concretely, let denote the map detecting . Since is an infinite loop space, this extends to a map , classifying a spherical bundle over . Hopkins’ and Mahowald’s result states that the Thom spectrum of this spherical bundle is . In light of this result, it is natural to ask: let . When is the free -ring with complex oriented?

Whatever general condition we obtain should also prove that the Thom spectrum is complex oriented, so let’s try to attack this case first (without using that it is ). We might naively try to do this by constructing a map of spaces over . However, such a map cannot exist: the image of the map on homotopy is the (complex) image of J, so it suffices to show that there are elements in the image of J which do not desuspend to . This is indeed true: the elements (which are defined for ) desuspends to with Hopf invariant . To be concrete, does not desuspend to .

Nonetheless, we can define a -orientation of . Recall that is the free -ring with , i.e., the Thom spectrum of the map classifying . There is a map of spaces over detecting in , and this defines a map of Thom spectra. This detects the fact that is null in . In fact, this implies that is null in for all .

Instead of trying to define a ring map of Thom spectra, let us try to directly define a complex orientation of (the integral Thom spectrum, which a posteriori we know is ), i.e., a factorization of the unit. An old theorem of Atiyah’s says that if is the map classifying the virtual vector bundle , where is the canonical line bundle on , then the Thom spectrum is equivalent to . The composite detects the spherical fibration over defined by the one-point compactification of (viewed as a virtual vector bundle), and upon looping this composite, the map detects .

We would therefore like to define a pointed map of pointed spaces over . However, there cannot be any such map: it would be adjoint to a map which is on the bottom cell of . In particular, the map would factor as . This is absurd: is not zero!

Let me end with a few remarks. At the prime , the spectrum is simply , so we can now ask about extending this map to a map . To answer this, we need to understand how is created from . In this paper, Beardsley shows that there is an element such that is the -quotient of by . Let us recall how this element is constructed. There is a fiber sequence . By construction, the composite is null, and hence factors through the cofiber of . There is a map (which won’t be an equivalence), and so we obtain a map . This defines the element . In fact, vanishes for not a power of . In the case that , the map , which I’ll denote by , factors through the inclusion . For instance, . These elements probably have to do with something awesome, relating to . Unfortunately, I don’t understand these elements very well yet, so I won’t say anything more about them.

Let me close by mentioning that there is yet another approach to understanding complex orientations, due to Hopkins and Lawson. I’ll return back to this post at some point to write down my understanding of what’s going on in their paper.
